Huon and the king are watching the battle from the castle between the Auvergnats and the king's men. They don't participate at first in the tournament.
The expression "les bornes d'Artus" refers to the eastern limits of the known world. See Roman d'Alexandre, Book 1, line 128.

At this point, after Berart's reproach, Huon switches sides and fights alongside the Auvergnats, his men. (In line 140 the king had announced that he wanted Huon on his side, which explains Huon's awkward position. See also lines 221 and 266.)

The illuminator places the king on the ground, not on his horse. See also line 410 where the king puts his hand on Saudin's shoulder with his eyes seemingly closed, an awkward movement when on horseback.

The translation is based on understand vera as deriving from the verb "veer" (refuse, forbid, prohibit). However the line could be transcribed as Mais ni onserent tant qui·l roy levera which would give the alternative translation: But they didn't dare until the king got up (there are multiple instances of the reflexive use of this verb without a reflexive pronoun, as in lines 2610, 2646, 2974, 8032 and others).

The word pelegrin (sometimes appearing as peregrin) can also be translated as "stranger" or even "traveler." The miniatures that depict this disguised devil (61R, 63R, 75V) show him in the typical traveling clothes of a medieval pilgrim. However, the hospitality shown him here obeys the Biblical injunction to show hospitality to a stranger, not only pilgrims.

This use of senator implies one who serves the Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire. See John Watts, The Making of Polities: Europe, 1300-1500: "In 1239 he [Frederick II] appealed to the cardinals as Senators of Rome, calling on them to convoke a general council of the Church at which the issues in play between himself and the pope could be judged" (p. 58). Cf. Roland's title in the Entrée d'Espagne.

If Tholomé were emended to "tal ome" an alternative translation would be: Everyone must serve such a man well, great and small (cf. T 4745 Servire debe esere tal sire [et] de grande [et] de menore), for it is not logical that the archbishop is speaking of Duke Tholomeus here.
